g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
In addition, investment in infrastructure is critical to the development of decarbonised economic
structures that generate growth, employment, and universal access to a wide ra
central to the SDG agenda: transportation, water, sanitation, electricity, flood protection, and irrigation.
, annual costs of reaching these goals by 2030 and putting their
oward decarbonisation may range between 2 and 8 percent of GDP, with the level
depending on spending efficiency. Notably, these costs need not exceed those of more polluting
. For transportation, this involves a shift toward more public
transportation (rail and bus), and decarbonised electricity for vehicles, combined wi
that densify cities and reduce distances between homes and jobs. By influencing the spatial distribution
of households and firms and the organisation of transportation, infrastructure has a strong bearing on
of providing services to different populations. Depending on country
context, the private sector may play a particularly important role in the financing of infrastructure
Many investments in infrastructure and sectoral capital stocks have long lifetimes. Given this, it may
be important to make sure that today’s investments be fully decarbonised at
the start or that they later
can be converted to zero carbon. Today’s investments in electric vehicles in settings where electricity
is produced with fossil fuels is an exampl
on has switched to renewable energies. For capital stocks that cannot be
decarbonised, countries may face costs of decommissioning well before the end of their useful lifetimes,
especially when it is needed to respect country commitments to future full dec
Changing economic, social and spatial patterns of development of the agriculture
sector provide the basis for sustained reductions in emissions from deforestation
benefits of sectoral policies that le
simultaneously promote economic development, improve living standards, reduce inequality, and create
(Bataille et al. 2018; Pye et al. 2016; Maroun and Schaeffer 2012; Richter et al. 2018;
Bataille et al. 2016b; La Rovere et al. 2018; Waisman et al. 2019)
challenging in developing countries, given large populations still lacking basic needs, previous
development paths show that finding synergies in development and climate objectives in the AFOLU
is Brazil, which has arguably shifted its development pathway to reduce
emissions and make progress towards several SDGs, though progress is not linear. Over the past two
decades, Brazil had made remarkable progress in implementing a sequence of policies
sectors. This policy package simultaneously increased minimum wages of low income families,
achieved universal energy access, and raised the quality of life and well
being for the large majority of
(Da Silveira Bezerra et al. 2017; Grottera et al. 2018, 2017; La Rovere et al. 2018)
led to significant social benefits, reduction of income inequality and poverty eradication
Bezerra et al. 2017; Grottera et al. 2017)
a decrease of the Gini coefficient and a rise in the
Regulatory instruments were used to limit deforestation rates, together with implemente
instruments that provided benefits to those protecting local ecosystems and enhancing land
(Soterroni et al. 2019, 2018; Bustamante et al. 2018; Nunes et al. 2017)
policies reinforced environmental regulation and command
based mechanisms to provide benefits to those protecting
Simonet et al. 2019; Nunes et al. 2017)
. The private sector, aligned with public policies and civil society,
plemented the Amazon Soy Moratorium, a voluntary agreement that bans trading of soybeans from
cropland associated with cleared Amazon rainforest and blacklists farmers using slave labour. This was
achieved without undermining production of soybean commodit
